Bush]] | predecessor = [[Makoto Fujimura]] | successor = [[Kamilah Forbes]] | birth_name = Melvin Lee Greenwood | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1942|10|27}} | birth_place = [[South Gate, California]], U.S. | spouse = {{marriage|Kimberly Payne|1993}} | children = 6 | module = {{Infobox musical artist|embed=yes | background = solo_singer | instrument = [[Singing|Vocals]], [[saxophone]], [[harmonica]] | genre = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[Pop music|pop]]}} | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1962–present | label = [[MCA Records|MCA]], [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], [[Liberty Records|Liberty]], [[Curb Records|Curb]], Country Crossing | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|https://leegreenwood.com/}} }} }} '''Melvin Lee Greenwood'''{{cite book |title= The Billboard Book Of Top 40 Country Hits: 1944-2006, Second edition|last=Whitburn |first=Joel |author-link=Joel Whitburn |year=2004 |publisher=Record Research |page=143}} (born October 27, 1942){{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|pages=166/7}} is an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter and [[saxophonist]].{{cite web|url=https://www.axs.com/interview-lee-greenwood-chats-his-4th-of-july-tour-family-and-his-musi-131483|title=Interview: Lee Greenwood chats his 4th of July tour, family and his music|date=July 1, 2018|access-date=July 24, 2020}} Active since 1962, he won a [[Grammy Awards|Grammy Award]] and he has charted 33 singles on the [[Hot Country Songs]] with 7 singles reaching the number one. He has sold more than 25 millions copies worldwide.{{Cite web |title=Lee Greenwood {{!}} Biography, Music & News |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/lee-greenwood/ |access-date=2024-09-11 |website=Billboard |language=en-US}}{{Cite web |title=LEE GREENWOOD HONORED WITH 25 MILLION ALBUMS SOLD WORLDWIDE PLAQUE AT GRAND OLE OPRY {{!}} Lee Greenwood |url=https://leegreenwood.com/lee-greenwood-honored-with-25-million-albums-sold-worldwide-plaque-at-grand-ole-opry/#:~:text=OPRY%20%7C%20Lee%20Greenwood-,LEE%20GREENWOOD%20HONORED%20WITH%2025%20MILLION%20ALBUMS,PLAQUE%20AT%20GRAND%20OLE%20OPRY&text=NASHVILLE,%20Tenn.,time,%20for%20his%2080th%20birthday? |access-date=2024-09-11 |language=en-US}} Greenwood is known for his patriotic [[signature song]] "[[God Bless the U.S.A.]]," which was originally released in the spring of 1984 and became a popular song, especially among members of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. That summer, it was included in a film about President [[Ronald Reagan]], the Republican [[President of the United States|presidential]] nominee, that was shown at the [[1984 Republican National Convention]].{{Cite news |last=Kastor |first=Elizabeth |date=1988-07-20 |title=STAYING IN TIME WITH THE REPUBLICANS |language=en-US |newspaper=Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1988/07/20/staying-in-time-with-the-republicans/d6d51280-369b-4abf-8729-2a4652849859/ |access-date=2023-07-04 |issn=0190-8286}} "God Bless the U.S.A." gained prominence during the [[1988 United States presidential election]] campaign, when Greenwood performed the song at the [[1988 Republican National Convention]] and at rallies for the Republican nominee, [[George H. W. Bush|George H.W. Bush]].{{Cite web |title=User Clip: Lee Greenwood God Bless the USA {{!}} C-SPAN.org |url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?c4502618/user-clip-lee-greenwood-god-bless-usa |access-date=2023-07-04 |website=www.c-span.org}}{{Cite web |title=User Clip: Lee Greenwood performs at Bush rally in Grand Rapids, MI; Nov. 2, 1988 {{!}} C-SPAN.org |url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?c5076745/user-clip-lee-greenwood-performs-bush-rally-grand-rapids-mi-nov-2-1988 |access-date=2023-07-04 |website=www.c-span.org}} The song was also featured in television advertisements for Bush.{{Cite web |title=The Living Room Candidate - Commercials - 1988 - Bush America |url=http://www.livingroomcandidate.org/commercials/1988/bush-america |access-date=2023-07-04 |website=www.livingroomcandidate.org}} It later became popular again during the [[Gulf War|Gulf War in 1991]] and after the [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001, attacks]] (becoming his highest charting pop hit, reaching number 16 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]), and again during the [[2016 United States presidential election|2016]], [[2020 United States presidential election]]s and 2024 as President [[Donald Trump]]'s rally introduction track. His seven number-ones on the U.S. [[Hot Country Songs]] list in his career: "[[Somebody's Gonna Love You]]", "[[Going, Going, Gone (Lee Greenwood song)|Going, Going, Gone]]", "[[Dixie Road (song)|Dixie Road]]", "[[I Don't Mind the Thorns (If You're the Rose)]]", "[[Don't Underestimate My Love For You]]", "[[Hearts Aren't Made to Break (They're Made to Love)]]", and "[[Mornin' Ride]]". His 1983 single "I.O.U." was also a top-five hit on the adult contemporary charts, and a number 53 on the [[Billboard Hot 100]]. ==Early life== Greenwood was born in [[South Gate, California]], a few miles south of Los Angeles. After his parents separated, he grew up in [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]], on the farm of his maternal grandparents.{{Cite web |title=Story Behind the Song: Lee Greenwood's 'God Bless the U.S.A.' |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/story-behind-the-song/2021/08/27/story-behind-song-lee-greenwoods-god-bless-u-s-a/5575603001/ |access-date=2023-07-04 |website=The Tennessean |language=en-US}} At the age of seven, he started singing in church. Greenwood did not serve in the United States military despite the universal draft at the time. He has said that he was given a 3A deferment for family hardship due to having children at age 17.{{cite web |title=Did 'God Bless the USA' Composer Lee Greenwood Flee to Canada to Avoid Vietnam War Draft?|publisher=Snopes.com|date=November 5, 2001|access-date=April 13, 2024|url=https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/lee-greenwood/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220917124325/https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/lee-greenwood/|archive-date=September 17, 2022}} He eloped to Reno, Nevada, with his first wife, Edna Greenwood, in 1960.{{cite news |title=No Time on Country Star Lee Greenwood’s Hands|url=https://www.mcall.com/1984/07/26/no-time-on-country-star-lee-greenwoods-hands/|publisher=Allentown Morning Call|date=July 26, 1984|author=Staff report|access-date=April 13, 2024}} ==Career== [[File:Reagan Contact Sheet C48860 (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|Greenwood speaking at the [[1988 Republican National Convention]], with [[President of the United States|President]] [[Ronald Reagan]] and [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]] [[Nancy Reagan]]]] [[File:President George H. W. Bush greets Lee Greenwood in the Oval Office.jpg|thumb|right|Greenwood with [[President of the United States|President]] [[George H. W. Bush]] in 1991]] [[File:Lee Greenwood by Gage Skidmore.jpg|right|thumb|Greenwood performing "God Bless the USA" at the [[Conservative Political Action Conference]] in 2013]] Greenwood founded his first band, The Apollos, in 1962. The band, which changed its name later to Lee Greenwood Affair, played mostly [[popular music|pop music]] and appeared mostly in [[gambling|casino]]s in [[Las Vegas, Nevada]]. In 1969, he joined the Chester Smith Band and had his first television appearance. A short time later, he worked with the country musician [[Del Reeves]]. A few records were recorded in Los Angeles with the [[Paramount Records (1969)|Paramount]] label. After the band broke up in the 1970s, Greenwood moved back to Las Vegas, where he worked as a [[blackjack]] dealer during the day and as a singer at night. In 1979, he was "discovered" in [[Reno, Nevada]], by Larry McFaden, the [[bandleader]] and [[bassist]] of [[Mel Tillis]]. After making some demo tapes, Greenwood was signed in 1981 by the [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] [[MCA Nashville Records|division]] of the [[MCA Records|MCA]] label (which had recently absorbed the Paramount label), and McFaden became his manager. The first single, the [[Jan Crutchfield]]-penned "It Turns Me Inside Out", made it to a spot in the top 20 of the country chart in 1981. The song had been written for [[Kenny Rogers]], Rogers recorded a version but decided to pass on it due to the sheer volume of songs he had been offered to record at the time. "[[Ring on Her Finger, Time on Her Hands]]" landed him in the country top 10. Each song was marketed heavily, particularly in the South Florida market by MCA Account Service Representative, Brad Fitzgerald, among others. Greenwood is known for writing and recording "[[God Bless the U.S.A.]]" in the early 1980s, and later "God Bless You Canada". The song gained renewed popularity following the launch of [[Operation: Desert Storm]] in 1991,{{cite news|title=Greenwood will entertain troops on Armed Forces TV|newspaper=The Daily News-Journal|date=January 24, 1991|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20935936/lee_greenwood_entertaining_troops_in/}} and again, 10 years later, following the September 11, 2001, attacks. "God Bless the U.S.A." re-entered the top 20 of the country charts in late 2001. Since then, Greenwood has played across the US, at many public events and commemorations of the attacks. The day before the [[inauguration of Donald Trump]], Greenwood performed at the [[Make America Great! Welcome Celebration]]. "God Bless the U.S.A." was used by [[Donald Trump]] as one of his [[campaign song]]s during the [[2016 United States presidential election|2016 presidential election]] and the [[2018 United States elections|2018 midterm elections]], and was used again during the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 presidential election]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MWtXrCBKvAg |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211222/MWtXrCBKvAg |archive-date=December 22, 2021 |url-status=live|title=FULL TRUMP RALLY: President Trump holds campaign rally in Dallas, Texas |publisher=Fox News |via=[[YouTube]] |access-date=October 20, 2019 |date=October 17, 2019}}{{cbignore}} Greenwood performed for [[Marsha Blackburn]] after her victory in her [[United States Senate election in Tennessee, 2018|Senate election]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F41fq79AdtA |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211222/F41fq79AdtA |archive-date=December 22, 2021 |url-status=live|title=Blackburn speaks after Tennessee Senate win|access-date=August 7, 2021 |publisher=Fox News |via=[[YouTube]]}}{{cbignore}}{{better source needed|date=November 2018}} On May 19, 2018, Lee Greenwood was awarded the MMP Music Award for his lifelong contribution to the music industry and inducted into the MMP Hall of Fame by Commander Joseph W. Clark. Greenwood made a surprise appearance at the [[2024 Republican National Convention|2024 RNC Convention]] on July 15, 2024 and performed "God Bless the U.S.A" while then former-President [[Donald Trump]], the [[2024 Republican Party presidential primaries|2024 Republican Presidential Nominee]], entered the arena which served as Trump's first appearance at a public event since surviving an [[Attempted assassination of Donald Trump in Pennsylvania|assassination attempt]] two days prior. ==National Council on the Arts== In September 2008, President [[George W. Bush]] nominated Greenwood to succeed [[Makoto Fujimura]] for a six-year term to the [[National Council on the Arts]]{{cite news|title=Bush appoints Lee Greenwood to National Arts Council|work=Los Angeles Times|date=November 3, 2008|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2008/11/lee-greenwoods.html}} expiring in 2014. He was confirmed by the Senate via voice vote in October 2008. In 2015, President [[Barack Obama]] nominated [[Esperanza Spalding]] to succeed Greenwood; however, the nomination was not acted upon by the Senate,{{cite news|title=PN1004 - Nomination of Esperanza Emily Spalding for National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities, 114th Congress (2015-2016)|work=Library of Congress|date=January 3, 2017|url=https://www.congress.gov/nomination/114th-congress/1004}} allowing Greenwood to continuing serving under Presidents Barack Obama and [[Donald Trump]] until the Senate confirmed a nominated successor.{{cite news|title=National Council on the Arts|work=National Endowment for the Arts|date=|url=https://www.arts.gov/about/leadership-staff/national-council-arts|access-date=November 13, 2021}} In June 2021, President [[Joe Biden]] nominated [[Kamilah Forbes]] to succeed Greenwood.{{cite news|title=PN755 - Nomination of Kamilah Forbes for National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities, 117th Congress (2021-2022)|work=Library of Congress|date=June 24, 2021|url=https://www.congress.gov/nomination/117th-congress/755}} In September 2021, Greenwood told [[Fox & Friends|Fox and Friends]] that the [[Presidency of Joe Biden|Biden administration]] sent him an email informing him that the president had already nominated his replacement on the National Council on the Arts and expressed his "shock" at being replaced.{{Cite web|last=Staff|first=Fox News|date=September 23, 2021|title=Lee Greenwood 'shocked' for being replaced on arts council by Biden administration|url=https://www.foxnews.com/media/lee-greenwood-shocked-for-being-replaced-on-arts-council-by-biden-administration|access-date=September 24, 2021|website=Fox News|language=en-US}} Forbes got confirmed by the Senate on February 17, 2022, via voice vote.{{Cite web |date=February 17, 2022 |title=PN755 - Nomination of Kamilah Forbes for National Foundation on the Arts and the Humanities, 117th Congress (2021-2022) |url=https://www.congress.gov/nomination/117th-congress/755 |access-date=March 9, 2022 |website=www.congress.gov}} ==Theater== In 1995, Greenwood took a break from his touring schedule to spend more time with his family. In his time off, he elected to build a theater in [[Sevierville, Tennessee]], and in April 1996, the Lee Greenwood Theater opened its doors. This gave Greenwood the opportunity to perform daily shows, in addition to being with his family.{{cite news|last1=James|first1=Gary|title=The Lee Greenwood Interview|url=http://www.theharbinger.org/xv/970422/JAMES.HTM|access-date=April 30, 2017|publisher=The Harbinger|date=April 22, 1997}} The theater operated for five seasons, and closed for Greenwood to continue touring. The former theater building is host to a church. ==The "God Bless the USA" Bible== In May 2021, to commemorate the 2001 attack on the World Trade Center, Greenwood published the ''[[God Bless the U.S.A. Bible]]''. This edition of the [[Bible]] has the [[Flag of the United States|U.S. flag]] on its leather cover and includes the texts of the [[United States Declaration of Independence|Declaration of Independence]], the [[Constitution of the United States|Constitution]], the [[United States Bill of Rights|Bill of Rights]], the [[Pledge of Allegiance]], and the chorus of "God Bless the USA" in Greenwood's handwriting.{{cite web |url=https://godblesstheusabible.com/product/god-bless-the-usa-bible/ |title=God Bless the USA Bible |author= |date= |website=God Bless the USA Bible |publisher= |access-date=March 29, 2024}} The text of the Bible was intended to be the [[New International Version]],{{cite news |url=https://eu.tennessean.com/story/news/religion/2021/05/18/lee-greenwoods-hit-song-inspires-new-god-bless-usa-bible/5082276001/ |title=Lee Greenwood's hit song inspires new 'God Bless the USA Bible' including America's founding documents |author=Holly Meyer |newspaper=Nashville Tennessean}} but Zondervan, the division of HarperCollins that owns the rights to the New International Version, withheld them rather than associate Christianity with U.S. nationalism, and it used the [[King James Version]], which is in the public domain in the United States.{{cite web |url=https://slate.com/human-interest/2021/09/lee-greenwood-bible-christian-publishing.html |title=The Uproar over the "Ultimate American Bible" |last=Olmstead |first=Molly |date=September 15, 2021 |website=Slate |publisher=The Slate Group |access-date=March 29, 2024}} It created further controversy in 2024 when former president [[Donald Trump]] promoted a new edition of it.{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2024/03/27/1241186975/donald-trump-bible-god-bless-usa |title=Cash-strapped Trump is now selling $60 Bibles, U.S. Constitution included |last=Treisman |first=Rachel |date=March 27, 2024 |website=NPR |publisher=National Public Radio |access-date=March 29, 2024}} ==Family== Greenwood is married to former [[Miss Tennessee USA]] Kimberly Payne, his fourth wife and fifth marriage.{{cite news|title=Lee Greenwood on Why Fourth Time's the Charm|publisher=The Boot|date=March 3, 2010|url=http://theboot.com/lee-greenwood-wife|access-date=March 3, 2010}} The former Miss Payne is 25 years his junior. They have two sons together, Dalton and Parker Greenwood.{{cite web |title=Lee Greenwood bio on Greenwood's official site |url=http://www.leegreenwood.com/index.php?p=360 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150912075606/http://www.leegreenwood.com/index.php?p=360 |archive-date=September 12, 2015 |access-date=March 3, 2010}} Previously he was married four times, the first two of them to Edna Greenwood, whom he divorced and remarried.{{cite news |title=No Time on Country Star Lee Greenwood’s Hands|url=https://www.mcall.com/1984/07/26/no-time-on-country-star-lee-greenwoods-hands/|publisher=Allentown Morning Call|date=July 26, 1984|author=Staff report|access-date=April 13, 2024}} He has four children from his earlier marriages.{{cite news|title=Lee Greenwood on Why Fourth Time's the Charm|publisher=The Boot|date=March 3, 2010|url=http://theboot.com/lee-greenwood-wife|access-date=March 3, 2010}} ==Discography== {{Main|Lee Greenwood discography}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * Wood, Gerry (1998).
